title: What are some well-known modern songs that don’t have any lyrics? - Quora

response.answer_text: I wrote an answer to a similar question: Ben Waggoner's answer to What is the highest charting song that has no lyrics? This includes Jan Hammer’s “Miami Vice Theme,” Vangelis’s “Chariots of Fire Theme,” Love Unlimited’s “Love’s Theme,” and Edgar Winter’s “Frankenstein.” But “well-known” made me think of songs that you commonly hear at sporting events. They may or may not get far on the charts, and they’re not necessarily what you’d want to listen to while relaxing at home—but for getting people up on their feet and cheering for the Possum Grape Marauders or whatever their home team is, these are ideal. Charting or not, they’re well known. I hear Gary Glitter’s “Rock and Roll, Part 2” pretty often. Gary Glitter himself got busted for child pornography and molestation, and he’s generally hated today. But I still hear “Rock and Roll Part 2” a lot at my university’s sporting events—possibly because he wasn’t that well known in the US, and people may not be aware of what he did. (See The Vibes of Victory, written before he was busted. I hope he’s not getting royalties for it now.) It also featured in the movie Joker. And it doesn’t have any lyrics except for people yelling “Hey!” and “Ugh!”  There’s also “Popcorn,” written by Gershon Kingsley in 1969 but probably best known as covered in 1972 by a band called Hot Butter. This is the kind of thing you might hear at basketball games as the team is warming up:  Zombie Nation’s “Kernkraft 400” does have synthesized voices saying “Zombie Nation”, and a bunch of voices singing “Oh-oh-oh-oh”, but I don’t think I’d call those lyrics as such. This is also a stadium favorite.  Stadiums are also known to play one of the most badass surf guitar anthems of all time, Dick Dale’s immortal “Misirlou,” which also featured prominently in Pulp Fiction:  And in the 1990s, the Chicago Bulls used to play “Sirius” by the Alan Parsons Project as the team was introduced. My university team uses it now (possibly because Scottie Pippen is an alumnus). Most of the YouTube videos of this song are blocked for me on copyright grounds, but you can hear it here:

Cory, I am a music lover over 4 decades. My musical taste for instrumentals may not fit with your definition of modern, but, I hope you will give these a chance at least once. You never know what you will fall in love with. Enjoy!
